input:
1. A 12-year-old boy presents with progressive stiffness and weakness in his lower limbs, causing frequent falls and difficulty walking. He reports occasional urinary urgency and mild sensory changes in his feet. His developmental milestones were initially normal, but over the past two years, his gait has become increasingly spastic and unsteady. Neurological examination reveals increased tone in the lower extremities, hyperactive reflexes, bilateral Babinski signs, and mild distal muscle wasting. Family history is notable for male relatives with similar motor difficulties in childhood. Brain MRI shows mild thinning of the corpus callosum without significant white matter abnormalities. Genetic testing identifies a pathogenic mutation in the L1CAM gene consistent with X-linked complicated spastic paraplegia type 1. Supportive therapies including physiotherapy and bladder management are initiated to improve his functional status.
What brings you in today?
output:
THINKING: The patient is a young boy, so I should keep my answer simple and focus on my symptoms, maybe mention feeling weaker or unsteady. I want to be honest but not overwhelm with details the doctor might not need.  
ANSWER: Um, I think I’ve been falling more often and I can’t walk as good as before. My legs feel really stiff, and sometimes I gotta go to the bathroom more quickly than I used to. It’s been happening for a while now.

input: 1. A 12-year-old boy presents with progressive stiffness and weakness in his lower limbs, causing frequent falls and difficulty walking. He reports occasional urinary urgency and mild sensory changes in his feet. His developmental milestones were initially normal, but over the past two years, his gait has become increasingly spastic and unsteady. Neurological examination reveals increased tone in the lower extremities, hyperactive reflexes, bilateral Babinski signs, and mild distal muscle wasting. Family history is notable for male relatives with similar motor difficulties in childhood. Brain MRI shows mild thinning of the corpus callosum without significant white matter abnormalities. Genetic testing identifies a pathogenic mutation in the L1CAM gene consistent with X-linked complicated spastic paraplegia type 1. Supportive therapies including physiotherapy and bladder management are initiated to improve his functional status.Can you tell me more about how these symptoms have been changing over time and how they are impacting your daily activities?
output: Well, um, I think I’ve been falling more and it’s harder to walk like I used to. Sometimes I feel like my legs won’t listen and I get tired really fast. It’s kind of messing up my day-to-day stuff and I don’t feel very steady anymore.

Supportive therapies including physiotherapy and bladder management are initiated to improve his functional status.Can you tell me how these symptoms have been affecting your daily activities and if you've noticed any other changes in your thinking, mood, or overall health recently?
output: Um, I guess it's been kinda hard. I fall more often now, and I can’t do things like I used to without getting tired or shaky. Sometimes I feel kinda down because I can't move as good, and I worry about what’s gonna happen later. I haven’t really noticed anything weird about my thinking or feelings, but I get really annoyed sometimes.

input: 1. A 12-year-old boy presents with progressive stiffness and weakness in his lower limbs, causing frequent falls and difficulty walking. He reports occasional urinary urgency and mild sensory changes in his feet. His developmental milestones were initially normal, but over the past two years, his gait has become increasingly spastic and unsteady. Neurological examination reveals increased tone in the lower extremities, hyperactive reflexes, bilateral Babinski signs, and mild distal muscle wasting. Family history is notable for male relatives with similar motor difficulties in childhood. Brain MRI shows mild thinning of the corpus callosum without significant white matter abnormalities. Genetic testing identifies a pathogenic mutation in the L1CAM gene consistent with X-linked complicated spastic paraplegia type 1. Supportive therapies including physiotherapy and bladder management are initiated to improve his functional status.Can you tell me more about how your symptoms have been evolving lately, and how they've been affecting your daily life and activities?
output: Well, I’ve been falling more… like I trip a lot and can’t really walk straight sometimes. It’s been making everything harder, like I can’t run or do the stuff I used to do with my friends. I feel kind of tired and some weird tingling in my feet, and I don’t always know what I should do or how to fix it.

input: 1. A 12-year-old boy presents with progressive stiffness and weakness in his lower limbs, causing frequent falls and difficulty walking. He reports occasional urinary urgency and mild sensory changes in his feet. His developmental milestones were initially normal, but over the past two years, his gait has become increasingly spastic and unsteady. Neurological examination reveals increased tone in the lower extremities, hyperactive reflexes, bilateral Babinski signs, and mild distal muscle wasting. Family history is notable for male relatives with similar motor difficulties in childhood. Brain MRI shows mild thinning of the corpus callosum without significant white matter abnormalities. Genetic testing identifies a pathogenic mutation in the L1CAM gene consistent with X-linked complicated spastic paraplegia type 1. Supportive therapies including physiotherapy and bladder management are initiated to improve his functional status.THINKING: To better differentiate between these neurological conditions, I need more information about the characteristics and distribution of sensory symptoms, as well as any history of systemic risk factors or other neurological signs. Regarding the involvement of the sensory system, specifics about the tingling, such as whether it is bilateral or unilateral, and whether other sensory modalities are affected, would be helpful. Additionally, details on any bowel or bladder dysfunction, which can occur with spinal cord lesions, would refine the differential. Understanding if there is any history of systemic conditions like diabetes or hypertension could also support a peripheral or central process. Lastly, assessing for features like tremor or rigidity can help clarify Parkinson's disease, and exploration of any visual changes could indicate optic nerve involvement typical of MS.
output: Um, sometimes my feet feel kind of numb or tingly, mostly both at the same time, but it’s hard to say. I don’t really notice anything else like trouble with my eyes or shaking, but I do go to the bathroom a lot and it’s been hard to control sometimes. I don’t have any other health problems that I know of—no idea about blood or anything like that.

Supportive therapies including physiotherapy and bladder management are initiated to improve his functional status.Are your symptoms, such as weakness, numbness, or tingling, more pronounced on one side of your body, or are they fairly symmetric? Also, have you experienced any back pain or stiffness?
output: Um, I think my stuff is kind of the same on both sides, but sometimes it’s hard to tell because I feel kind of numb or tingly a little, especially in my feet. I haven’t really had any back pain, but my legs do feel stiff sometimes, like they don’t move quite right.

Supportive therapies including physiotherapy and bladder management are initiated to improve his functional status.Are you experiencing any weakness or changes in muscle strength in your legs or arms? Also, do you notice increased reflexes, such as brisk knee or ankle reflexes, or abnormal reflexes like a Babinski sign?
output: Yeah, I think my legs feel really heavy sometimes, and I keep tripping over things. My doctor said my reflexes are kind of jumpy and I’ve seen my toes curl when he touches my feet, so I guess that means something? I don’t really understand all of it, but I feel like I’m getting worse.

output: Um, well, I think there were times when things looked a little fuzzy or blurry, but I'm not really sure if it was just my eyes or what. Sometimes my eye might hurt a little, but I didn't lose all my vision or anything like that.

output: Um, sometimes I feel like I’m worse when I try to walk, like I get more unsteady or like my legs don’t want to cooperate, but I don’t really know if that’s new or if I just imagine it.
